TopicTitle: Anyone can show me what does a "Gilly Ridgeline" looks like?

Articles.Content: If you can’t find any, try enabling the BG cheats to indicate where all the surface features are. They’re usually biome specific but Gilly has so few biomes that you’ll probably find some wherever you go. There’s also the SCANsat BTDT part which can detect them at short ranges.
I know it is located in Midlands but i cannot find where it is in midlands. So this is why i would like to take a look on what i am looking for
they look like this, and are very common. I made a rover to visit gilly, but with no wheels, just a lot of monoprop and thrusters as it is way easier. You can find them pretty everywhere
Look in this thread. I believe it has what you're looking for.

Well, they are pretty obviously not like regular surface/ground. And since they are not tied to a fixed position, you need to wander around util you find it. 

However, from the wiki:

Quote

...surface features are similar to terrain scatter. Terrain scatter tends to be more prolific and can make it difficult to identify surface features. The largest difference is surface features can be interacted with, while terrain scatter allows objects to pass right through.

 

Which means that is a good idea to disable terrain scatter while looking for surface features. Wasting time trying to inspect a mirage is not fun.

 

PS: sorry for wasting moderation time by reporting a "double post" which was actually a glitch with my browser. ...or I'd rather say "D'oh!"

20 hours ago, Grogs said:

Look in this thread. I believe it has what you're looking for.

This is a good ref page

Thanks a lot

Am I right that this Gilly Ridgeline thing cannot be picked up by a Kerbal, it is only for scanning by one of those rover arms, right?

Oh, I see the wiki page does say which Surface Features can be picked up by Kerbals. https://wiki.kerbalspaceprogram.com/wiki/Surface_features

So if you don't have one of those rover scanning arms, then these big features are not worth any Science points to visit, right?
